captions.text:
>>HEY!
YOU AGAIN!

>>NATALIE!
ISN'T IT LITERALLY IRONIC HOW WE RUN INTO
EACH OTHER EVERY DAY?

>>GOOD SIR-- >>ALLOW ME TO DEFINE
IRONIC FOR YOU FELLOW, "THERE'S A VERBAL

IRONY,
DRAMATIC IRONY, AND SITUATIONAL IRONY.

WHICH IS THE ONE YOU SPEAK OF.
THAT'S THE INCONGRUITY OF THE ACTUAL SEQUENCE

OF EVENTS AND
THE NORMAL OR EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THE SEQUENCES

OF EVENTS.
SO WHEN YOU SAY THAT RUNNING INTO YOUR

FRIEND EVERYDAY IS IRONIC, IT'S NOT IRONIC,
IT'S JUST INTERESTING.
IRONY TAUGHT!

>>WHAT? WHO ARE YOU?
>>I'M CAPTAIN IRONY HERE TO EDUCATE THE

MASSES ON
THE USE OF THE WORD IRONY.

HIPSTERS LOVE ME.
>>I HAVE ALWAYS WANTED TO KNOW HOW TO USE

THE WORD IRONY.
I NEVER REALLY MEANT ANYBODY THAT KNOWS...

>>SHUSH.
WAIT!

SO YOU DON'T EVEN HAVE THE POWER TO RESTORE
BALANCE AND YOUR CATCH PHRASE IS IRONY TAUGHT?

A CAPTAIN WITHOUT SUPER POWERS.
NOW THAT'S IRONIC.

>>NO, IT'S NOT.
BELIEVE ME.

>>IRONICALLY, SOMETIMES I THINK IT'D BE
NICE TO NOT HAVE POWERS.

>>DID YOU JUST HEAR YOURSELF?
YOU JUST PUT THE WORD IRONICALLY IN FRONT
OF A TOTALLY UNRELATED SENTENCE.

THAT'S LIKE SAYING IRONICALLY THE OCEAN
IS NEAT!

>>YOU KNOW WHAT'S IRONIC?
A CAPTAIN WHO'S A WOMAN, AM I RIGHT?

>>OH, THAT'S SO FUNNY TO ME.
>>REALLY?

>>NO.
I WAS BEING IRONIC.

IRONY TAUGHT!
>>WELL CAPTAIN IRONY.

I'LL HAVE YOU KNOW I GOT MY REAL POWERS
FROM A NUCLEAR BLAST.

[GROANS OF PAIN] >>WHO ARE YOU?
>>THE NUCLEAR NINJA.

I JUST PUNCH PEOPLE WHO MISPRONOUNCE THE NUCLEAR.
HOW ARE YOU DOING SIR?

>>WELL DESPITE YOUR BEST EFFORTS I'M STILL
DOING REALLY GOOD.

>>ARE YOU DOING GOOD?
>>OR ARE YOU DOING WELL?

>>GOOD AND WELL ARE DIFFERENT.
[SMACK] [SMACK]

>>OH COME ON GUYS!
YOU'RE EVEN MORE RIDICULOUS THAN THE NUCLEAR

NINJA DUDE!
[GROANS OF PAIN] >>HAD TO BE DONE.

comments.author: Rune Spark

comments.text:
The notion that good can't be used in place of well is false. Good has 
multiple meanings, one of which is free from infirmity or sorrow, which is 
perfectly synonymous with the desired meaning of well. To say that saying, 
"I'm doing good" means you are literally doing good deeds is like saying 
that, "I'm doing well" means you're doing a spring of water, which doesn't 
make any sense. So yeah, I'm doing good.

Here is an entry from the Merriam-Webster dictionary:

Usage Discussion of GOOD

An old notion that it is wrong to say “I feel good” in reference to health 
still occasionally appears in print. The origins of this notion are 
obscure, but they seem to combine someone's idea that good should be 
reserved to describe virtue and uncertainty about whether an adverb or an 
adjective should follow feel. Today nearly everyone agrees that both good 
and well can be predicate adjectives after feel. Both are used to express 
good health, but good may connote good spirits in addition to good health.

Side note: Never let anyone tell you how to talk. English is all made up 
and changes constantly (the same as any language.) While there are 
conventions considered to be proper, working outside of them is not 
incorrect. If it has meaning to the speaker then it's language, whether it 
is or isn't accepted as proper by the listener is moot. If someone speaks 
Japanese to me, just because I don't understand it doesn't mean it isn't a 
language. There are countless dialects in the English language. If I say 
something that isn't "proper" English, then I merely created a new and 
unique dialect. So shove it you grammar Nazis. And don't even get me 
started on how loose punctuation can be.﻿
comments.author: SanguineSaint21

comments.author: odduckOasis

+odduckOasis In a word: colloquialism. But I still like to tease people

comments.author: Ravenwell

comments.text:
I think a bit of that line of thought is in error. To say that the English 
language changes all the time anyways and so it's okay to use words 
incorrectly is justifying the improper spelling of words along with 
improper grammar. While it can be generally accepted that the word "good" 
can denote more than action- this has only become accepted because the 
general populous has decided it to be so- hence Webster changing things. I 
think it goes along the lines of "Well, they're going to say it anyways, so 
might as well make it official."
Which is why we have words like "funner" and people say things like "More 
better". Most of the time, I just sigh and ignore it, tho the use of "your" 
in place of "you're" is still a pet peeve. But regardless of English being 
"made up"- that sort of correct grammar usage will never change.

All in all. It's comedy, no need to get so riled up.
comments.author: odduckOasis

comments.text:
Other possible Grammar Superheros:
Grammar Nazi: A Nazi soldier who shows up when people use incorrect grammar 
on papers.
Spelling Bee: A person in a bee costume that shows up when people misspell 
things.
Improper Pronoun Professor: An old man who corrects people when they use 
improper pronouns.
Helping Verb Helper: Corrects people who don't use the proper Helping Verbs.
Sergent Quotations: A gruff military Sergent who insults people who don't 
use quotation marks.
Plagiarism Pilgrim: A Puritan who will whack people who plagiarize. 
Silent E-Man: Wearing tights embroidered with an E, this character will 
show up when people misuse or forget the Silent E.
Can you think of any others?﻿

comments.author: cupcakesimulation

comments.text:
+Selena Barrows Okay, I wouldn't say "dark humor" is an effective means by 
which to identify irony, as humor itself is already subjective. If I don't 
find it funny, is it then not ironic? Additionally, the former situation of 
the two you provided can be viewed as paradox with the latter: If the cat 
chased the mouse into the road and got hit by a car, but it was on a busy 
highway in the middle of rush hour, I would EXPECT it to get hit by the car 
(or at the very least not be surprised if it had), and thus the situation 
may no longer be considered ironic. I would stick with your second example 
more so.
comments.author: Ravenwell

comments.text:
Ironic: Dark humor (The cat chased the mouse into the road and got hit by a 
car) or the opposite of what you'd expect. (The cat enjoyed the bath.) 
That's how I learned it.
